morning_call_markdown:
### Executive Summary
- Microsoft Patch Tuesday released 100+ fixes including at least one actively exploited Windows Desktop Window Manager 0‑day; urgent for all endpoints and servers.
- Multiple critical vulns in Fortinet products, Apache Struts 2, SmarterMail, MongoDB, Node.js, Gogs, and SAP increase exposure of internet‑facing and developer / email infrastructure.
- Active campaigns continue against financial targets: Magecart card skimming, Android banking malware with ransomware capabilities, RAT delivery via phishing and RMM tools, and OAuth/token theft via supply-chain attacks.

---

### High-priority items (immediate attention)

- **Actively exploited Windows 0‑day + January 2026 Patch Tuesday**
  - What happened: Microsoft patched 113–114 CVEs including an in‑the‑wild Desktop Window Manager 0‑day and two more zero‑days; CISA also added a Windows vuln to KEV.
  - Why it matters operationally: Unpatched Windows clients/servers are high‑value targets for initial access and local privilege escalation in ransomware and intrusions.
  - Recommended immediate actions for the SOC today:  
    • Verify via patch/ESU dashboards which Windows builds are still missing Jan‑2026 patches (incl. KB5073724 for Win10 ESU) and escalate non‑compliant critical systems.  
    • Prioritize hunting for exploit/POC activity: abnormal DWM crashes, new unsigned binaries spawning from `dwm.exe`, unusual LSASS access or token theft post‑patch (T1068, T1055).

- **Fortinet critical vulnerabilities (FortiOS, FortiSwitchManager, FortiSandbox, FortiSIEM)**
  - What happened: Multiple advisories and research note RCE/SSRF and long‑standing remote root issues across Fortinet products (FortiOS, FortiSwitchManager, FortiSandbox SSRF, FortiSIEM RCE).
  - Why it matters operationally: These devices are often perimeter or monitoring infrastructure; compromise provides network‑wide foothold and visibility into our logs.
  - Recommended immediate actions for the SOC today:  
    • Confirm with network/security engineering which Fortinet products/versions we run; check against latest Fortinet & CIS advisories and ensure emergency patch plan is in flight.  
    • Increase monitoring on Fortinet management interfaces: failed logins, config changes, suspicious admin sessions from unfamiliar IPs, unusual outbound connections from these appliances.

- **Critical web/email stack vulns: Apache Struts 2, SmarterMail RCE, MongoDB “Mongobleed”, Node.js**
  - What happened:  
    • Critical Apache Struts 2 bug enabling data theft/SSRF.  
    • SmarterMail RCE with public PoC impacting 8k+ hosts.  
    • MongoDB CVE‑2025‑14847 (“Mongobleed”) and Node.js security releases across all branches.
  - Why it matters operationally: These are common in portals, line‑of‑business apps and email systems; exploitation can lead to direct data theft, mailbox takeover, or pivot to internal networks.
  - Recommended immediate actions for the SOC today:  
    • Identify any externally exposed Struts, SmarterMail, MongoDB, and Node.js‑based services (ask app and infra owners; check ASM/CMDB) and verify patch/mitigation status.  
    • Hunt in WAF/web/mail logs for anomalies since Dec: unexpected `/debug`, `/admin`, or SSRF‑style outbound requests from app servers; unusual child processes spawned by mail/web services (T1190, T1505).

- **Gogs zero‑day added to CISA KEV + Target source code leak**
  - What happened: CISA flagged an exploited Gogs vuln with no patch yet; concurrently, a major retailer confirmed leaked source code and accelerated Git lockdown.
  - Why it matters operationally: Git services and source code repos are high‑value for supply‑chain attacks, credential harvesting, and implanting backdoors.
  - Recommended immediate actions for the SOC today:  
    • Confirm if any self‑hosted Gogs or similar lightweight Git instances exist (including in dev/test); if yes, restrict external access immediately, enforce SSO/MFA, and monitor closely.  
    • Review last 7–14 days of Git / CI logs for anomalous clone/push from unusual IPs, access to sensitive repos, new SSH keys/tokens, or unexpected branch/CI config changes (T1552, T1195).

- **Active fraud/malware campaigns: Magecart card skimming, AsyncRAT via Python/Cloudflare, Android banking malware deVixor, OAuth theft via n8n supply chain**
  - What happened:  
    • New Magecart campaign stealing card data at checkout; broader campaign hitting Amex/Diners/MasterCard since 2022.  
    • AsyncRAT delivered via Python + Cloudflare, performance‑review phishing, and RMM‑abusing malware.  
    • Banking malware deVixor with ransomware features targeting Android; supply‑chain compromise of n8n aiming at OAuth credential theft.
  - Why it matters operationally: Direct risk to card data, customer endpoints, staff workstations, and SaaS integrations (OAuth tokens) used across financial workflows.
  - Recommended immediate actions for the SOC today:  
    • Intensify web/app monitoring on payment pages: unexpected JS changes, calls to unfamiliar domains, or inline scripts injected post‑deployment; coordinate with web teams on file integrity checks.  
    • Tighten email/web gateway rules and EDR hunts for: RMM tool misuse (AnyDesk, ScreenConnect, etc.), Python‑spawned network beacons, new persistence for AsyncRAT families, suspicious OAuth app approvals in IdP/SSO (T1059, T1219, T1071, T1556).

---

### Monitoring & detection recommendations

- **Patch Tuesday & Windows 0‑day**
  - EDR + Windows logs (Sysmon, Security): monitor for unusual child processes from `dwm.exe`, `explorer.exe` escalating to admin tools; spikes in exploit‑like crashes or process injection (T1055, T1068).
- **Perimeter / Fortinet exposure**
  - Firewall/VPN/Device logs: watch for login attempts from new geos, brute‑force patterns, config changes outside change windows, new admin accounts on Fortinet gear (T1078, T1098, T1562).
- **Web app / Struts / SmarterMail / SAP / Node.js**
  - WAF, reverse proxy, web/app server logs: hunt for abnormal HTTP methods, SSRF patterns (internal IPs in URLs), serialized payloads, or requests to JMX/admin paths; alert on mail service spawning shells (T1190, T1505, T1210).
- **Git / Gogs / CI‑CD**
  - Git server and CI logs: flag mass clones, access from atypical IP ranges, unexpected PAT/SSH key creation, and pipeline file changes (GitHub Actions, GitLab CI, etc.) (T1552, T1608).
- **Magecart & card data skimming**
  - Web server + CDN logs and content integrity tools: monitor for new or modified JS on payment pages, outbound calls from checkout pages to non‑approved domains, and changes not tied to deployments (T1059.007, T1530).
- **Phishing, BitB, “performance review” lures, QR/“quishing”**
  - Email, secure web gateway, EDR: detect HTML attachments, lookalike domains, Browser‑in‑the‑Browser windows (multiple nested frames), and user clicks leading to credential prompts; correlate with new sign‑ins from new devices (T1566, T1110).
- **RMM abuse and AsyncRAT activity**
  - EDR and network sensors: alert on new RMM installs, RMM processes executing PowerShell/cmd, long‑lived outbound connections to cloud/CF fronted domains, and typical RAT persistence (registry Run keys, scheduled tasks) (T1105, T1219, T1053).
- **Android banking malware & mobile fraud**
  - MDM/MAM and fraud analytics: watch for new high‑risk apps, unusual device changes followed by high‑value transactions, and repeated failed 2FA from mobile; coordinate with fraud team on abnormal patterns (T1476, T1647 – Mobile).

---

### Medium-term follow-ups

- **Coordinate full rollout of Jan‑2026 Microsoft patches**
  - Ensure risk‑based prioritization for internet‑facing servers, domain controllers, VDI, and high‑privileged admin workstations; validate with compliance dashboards.
- **Comprehensive review of Fortinet and other perimeter appliances**
  - Confirm inventory, firmware standards, management plane exposure (no direct internet where avoidable), and ensure logging to SIEM with proper parsing/enrichment.
- **Web application and email security hardening**
  - Assess all Struts‑based and legacy Java stacks, SmarterMail or other third‑party mail/webmail, and apply WAF rules, version upgrades, and code scanning for injection/SSRF patterns.
- **Source code and CI/CD security posture**
  - Review policies for Git access (MFA, least privilege, network controls), secret scanning in repos, backup/restore testing, and incident playbooks for source‑code leaks/backdoor discovery.
- **OAuth/SaaS and automation platform risk management**
  - Work with cloud and app teams to inventory n8n and similar workflow tools, reduce token scopes, implement conditional access on critical SaaS, and enable anomaly detection for OAuth app grants.
- **Ransomware and extortion readiness**
  - Re‑validate backups, EDR coverage, DC and hypervisor hardening, and user awareness around phishing and RMM misuse; refresh playbooks for double‑extortion and regulatory/compliance impact.
